text: Quitline Tobacco Interventions in Hospitalized Patients A Randomized Trial
H ospitalization provides a unique opportunity for tobacco use interventions.
In addition to the long-term health benefits of quitting smoking, there maybe additional benefits, such as reduced hospital readmission rates.

entities.text: long-term health benefits of quitting smoking

text: 1,2 As reviewed recently, 3 interventions can be efficacious, but few have been implemented into routine clinical practice.
This may reflect unique challenges to tobacco use interventions in hospitals, such as logistic barriers (e.g., interruptions for procedures).

Nonetheless, counseling that begins during hospitalization and includes supportive contacts for 41 month after discharge increases cessation rates at 6−12 months (pooled OR=1.65, 95% CI=1.44, 1.90, in meta-analysis); interventions that do not continue after hospital discharge are not efficacious.
However, sustained follow-up counseling maybe difficult and expensive for hospitals to provide.
Most trials demonstrating efficacy employ tobacco treatment specialists (TTSs) or equivalent study personnel to provide in-hospital interventions and follow-up.
The authors' institution uses TTSs to provide bedside counseling, with referral initiated by nurses during the admissions process.

Challenges with implementing this model in practice include the need to train these providers, devising mechanisms for identifying and referring smokers, reimbursement for services, and logistics of providing follow-up.

Despite more than 20 years of experience using TTS services for hospitalized smokers, Mayo Clinic does not currently provide extended follow-up because of cost and feasibility, suggestive of the need for new approaches.
Telephone quitlines, currently available in all states, could provide both intensive in-hospital interventions and extended follow-up.
Although quitline efficacy is well established in ambulatory populations, 9,10 its effectiveness in hospitalized patients is unknown.
The overall objective of this study was to determine whether quitlines could be used as an effective means of delivering intervention services to hospitalized smokers.
Approximately 5 million smokers are hospitalized in the U.S. annually, so the potential impact of quitlines effectively applied to this population could be considerable.

The authors conducted an RCT of 600 residents of Olmsted County, MN admitted to one of two Mayo Clinic hospitals to test the hypothesis that quitline services are effective in helping these patients quit, as measured by self-reported 7 - day point prevalence abstinence at 6 months after discharge.
This study was approved by the Mayo Clinic IRB and was registered before initiation (ClinicalTrials.gov ID: NCT01575145).
The study was conducted in the two Mayo Clinic hospitals in Rochester, MN.

As apart of standard clinical care, at hospital admission, every patient is asked by a nurse about tobacco use, a brief tobacco use history is obtained, and current users are offered both nicotine-replacement therapy (NRT) and a consult with a TTS.
Eligible patients included those who lived in the areas covered by ZIP codes within Olmsted County, MN (55901−55906).
This included all residents of Olmsted County and some who resided just outside of the county.
This design minimized referral bias and facilitated follow-up.
Other inclusion criteria included age ≥18 years, 4100 cigarettes lifetime consumption and history of smoking any cigarettes within the prior week, and telephone access.
Exclusion criteria included current tobacco use treatment initiated before hospitalization and inability to provide consent (e.g., patients unable to communicate because of acute illness).
The intent to maintain long-term abstinence from smoking was not an inclusion criterion.
For women of childbearing potential, a pregnancy test was performed.
If a potential subject was pregnant or lactating, the subject could still be enrolled, but NRT was not offered.
Those patients who had requested TTS counseling at admission were also approached for study participation.
A data query ("sniffer") interrogated the electronic medical record five times daily to determine which patients may meet study criteria, with results e-mailed to study personnel.
Study personnel approached those potentially eligible after review of the electronic medical record and confirmed eligibility.
The study was introduced as a study of ways to "help patients stay off cigarettes when they leave the hospital."
Study personnel were available consistently during weekday daytime hours and during some weekend hours.
Enrolled patients completed written informed consent.
Interventions were delivered by study personnel.
These personnel were trained by Mayo Clinic Nicotine Dependence Center staff, who periodically reviewed their performance, but were not TTSs.

entities.text: trained by Mayo Clinic Nicotine Dependence Center staff

text: Intervention scripts are provided in the Appendix (available online).

The brief control (~5 - minute) intervention consisted of the first four of the 5A's (Ask, Advise, Assess, Assist, and Arrange), including advice and brief assistance in reviewing tips to help maintain abstinence using a brochure.
The brochure included the study quitline number but did not specifically encourage its use.

To the intervention group, a single brief quitline facilitation intervention (also ~5 minutes in duration, slightly modified from that piloted in the authors' prior studies of presurgical patients 11 ) was delivered.
Based on principles of Social Cognitive Therapy, it included advice to quit and quitline information.
Its purpose was to facilitate quitline utilization, not to provide assistance with quitting, but to overcome cognitive barriers to quitline utilization.
A written brochure that included information about the quitline and a wallet-sized "quit-card" were provided.

If patients were amenable, study personnel then contacted the quitline provider, preferably by direct phone call ("warm handoff") to enroll the patient for quitline services and arrange for an initial counseling call.
If this direct contact could not be made, faxed referrals were sent to the quitline provider.

Based on early experiences that it was difficult for the quitline to re-contact patients while in hospital, the goal was to complete the first counseling session immediately after the in-hospital quitline intake.
Subsequent counseling sessions were scheduled by quitline counselors.

All subjects were offered NRT while hospitalized (consistent with clinical routine and ordered through the existing tobacco use protocol) and a free 2 - week supply of nicotine patches at discharge, with instructions to purchase over-the-counter patches if further therapy was desired.

They were dosed according to current cigarette consumption, with those smoking fewer than ten cigarettes per day receiving a 14 - mg patch and those smoking more than ten cigarettes per day receiving a 21 - mg patch.
Patches were chosen as reflecting common clinical practice, and a 2 - week supply chosen as potentially acceptable for hospitals to provide in practice.
Quitline services were provided by the National Jewish Health quitline (Denver, CO).
For this study, a dedicated toll-free number was designated for study participants so that utilization could be tracked.
Referral to the quitline was made by faxed referral form (provided by National Jewish Health) or by directly calling the tollfree number.
The telephone counselors were briefed regarding the study and practical considerations of scheduling calls in these patients.
However, the quitline intervention itself was not specifically tailored to the hospital setting to maximize the potential generalizability of results.
Subjects were randomized using dynamic randomization allocation based on the Mayo Clinic Study Data Management System, a proprietary web application for data entry and management.

Randomization was stratified based on nursing unit to ensure the number of subjects assigned to each of the two intervention groups remained balanced within that unit, enhancing the homogeneity of admitting diagnoses between groups.
Assessments were performed at the time of enrollment and initial intervention, 7 days after enrollment and at 30 days and 6 months after hospital discharge.
By the time of the 7 - day and subsequent assessments, most patients were at home, making telephone contact necessary.
Subjects who completed initial baseline assessments received $20 remuneration.
Subjects completing study procedures at 6 months, including provision of a urine specimen if they selfreported abstinence, received an additional $70.
Baseline information included demographics, comorbidities, admission indication, major procedures received in hospital, and duration of hospitalization.
Smoking history information included prior quit attempts, the Fagerström test for Nicotine Dependence, and intent to initiate smoking behavioral change according to the contemplation ladder.
Other measures of intent and self-efficacy, as used and validated in prior work, 11,15 were also assessed.
Participants were also queried regarding their concerns about the health risks of smoking.

entities.text: queried regarding their concerns about the health risks of smoking.

text: Patients were asked about 7 - day point prevalence and continuous abstinence at each assessment after baseline.
Those patients self-reporting abstinence at the 6 - month assessment were asked to provide a urine specimen.
If patients could not be reached by telephone for the 6 - month assessment, a letter was mailed to them.
This letter included $2 cash and a postcard with two response items (7 - day point prevalence abstinence, and whether they used the quitline).
Quitline utilization was measured using records from the quitline provider, including the number and duration of calls.
Quitline utilization was defined as having completed at least one counseling call after the initial intake call.
At 6 months, several questions regarding experience and satisfaction with quitline services were administered.

Because patients could still be using NRT at the time of assessment, urine anabasine levels were used to verify smoking status among those patients reporting abstinence at 6 months, with levels of o2 ng/mL considered to confirm abstinence.
Options for providing specimens including via mail, direct return to the clinical facility, or pick-up at home by study personnel.
Data analysis occurred between September 2014 and March 2015.
The primary endpoint was self-reported 7 - day point prevalence abstinence at 6 months after hospital discharge.
The reviews of Rigotti et al. and France and colleagues found that 6 - month abstinence rates after hospitalization averaged approximately 20%.

Based on the observed effects for efficacious interventions in recent reviews of hospitalized patients (pooled OR¼1.65), the authors hypothesized that this abstinence rate would beat least 30% for patients who receive the experimental intervention.
Based on these assumptions, a total sample size of 600 (300 per group) provided statistical power of 81% (two-tailed, α¼0.05) to detect a difference between experimental groups.
Unless otherwise specified, data are presented using mean (SD) for continuous variables and frequency counts and percentages for nominal variables.
Characteristics were compared using the twosample t-test for continuous variables and the chi-square test for nominal variables.
For the primary analysis, three methods were used to account for subjects who could not be contacted or who discontinued study participation prior to the 6 - month assessment:
1. Those with missing outcomes were considered to be smoking and abstinence was compared between treatment groups using the chi-square test.
2. Those with missing outcomes were excluded and abstinence was compared between treatment groups using the chi-square test.
3. Multiple imputation analysis was performed in which 500 complete data sets were imputed and analyzed using logistic regression with results combined using Reuben's rules.

Multiple imputation is a statistical technique used to analyze incomplete data sets, in which missing data is imputed (filled) with a variety of possible values and each resulting data set is analyzed.

For the multiple imputation analysis, the imputation model included abstinence outcomes, any use of NRT after hospital discharge, completing at least one counseling session, and all characteristics listed in, with the exception of race, ethnicity, and comorbidities.
Secondary analyses were performed to assess patient characteristics potentially associated with abstinence or completing any counseling.
The bivariate association between each characteristic and outcome was assessed using the chi-square test, and also using logistic regression with treatment group included as a covariate.
In all cases, two-tailed p≤0.05 was considered statistically significant.

Of 5,338 patient admissions initially screened as eligible between May 2012 and August 2014, 2,978 admissions met eligibility criteria (eligible admissions are reported rather than eligible patients, as some were admitted more than once during the recruitment period and patients could only be enrolled once).
A total of 2,360 admissions initially identified by the "sniffer" involved patients who were ineligible upon initial review by study staff).
Of the 1,532 admissions who were approached for consent (representing 51% of eligible admissions), 1,409 were confirmed to be eligible.
Of these, 600 subjects (47%) provided informed consent and were randomized.
Numbers in the remainder of this article describe the number of unique subjects.

When compared with those patients who were approached, those who screened as potentially eligible but were not approached for logistic reasons (such as brief weekend admissions when no study staff were available to seethe patient) were less likely to have requested NRT or a Nicotine Dependence Center consult at admission via the nurse-managed protocol (Appendix, available online).
When compared with those patients who enrolled, those who declined enrollment were less likely to have requested NRT or a Nicotine Dependence Center consult.
Thus, although the authors attempted to recruit all eligible patients, those who enrolled demonstrated greater interest in tobacco intervention services at admission.
Demographic and medical characteristics were similar between groups.

Tobacco use characteristics were also similar, with the exception that a significantly higher proportion of subjects in the quitline group planned to stop smoking for good, although the proportions were high in both groups.
Overall, 37% of subjects reported being very likely to stay off cigarettes after leaving the hospital, and 45% were very or extremely sure that they could succeed in quitting.
The majority in both groups had made multiple prior attempts to quit smoking.

Approximately three in four subjects were very worried that smoking would damage their health, yet only approximately one in three agreed or strongly agreed that their smoking contributed to their needing to be in the hospital.
NRT was initiated in hospital in 259 (43%) subjects, with similar proportions in both groups, and identical proportions in each group (77%) accepted free NRT at hospital discharge (.
The quitline intake call was completed by 195 subjects, all but one of them in the quitline group; thus, 65% of the quitline group completed the intake call.
All intake calls were completed in the hospital.
Referrals were faxed to the quitline providers for 58 of the subjects in the quitline group; of these, 21 completed the intake call.

Of the 194 subjects in the quitline group who completed the intake call (which includes the 21 who received faxed referral), 128 (66%) completed the first coaching call, with 83 (65% of those completing the first coaching call) doing so before hospital discharge.

The proportion of subjects who completed the first coaching call was identical in the 21 subjects who completed the intake call after faxed referral and those who completed the intake call without faxed referral (66%).
The one individual in the control group who completed the intake call did not complete a coaching session.
Of the 128 who completed at least one coaching call, 71 (55%) completed a single call, 19 (15%) completed two calls, 9 (7%) completed three calls, and 29 (23%) completed four or more calls.
For those subjects who could be contacted at 6 months and who completed at least one coaching call, satisfaction with quitline services was high (Appendix, available online).
Follow-up rates at 7 days, 30 days, and 6 months were similar in both the quitline and control groups (86% vs 91% at 7 days, 80% vs 87% at 30 days, and 70% vs 74% at 6 months, respectively,).
Self-reported point prevalence abstinence rates were not significantly different between groups at any assessment).
This was true regardless of whether those who were lost to followup were included as smoking or not, and when imputation was used to account for missing data.
Similar proportions of patients reported using NRT after hospital discharge in both groups.
Biochemical confirmation of smoking status was sought for those reporting abstinence at 6 months.

Of those subjects reporting abstinence (72 subjects in both the control and quitline groups), approximately half provided urine samples and 39 [54%] subjects in control and quitline groups, respectively).
Of those who provided urine samples, anabasine levels were consistent with abstinence in 21 (60%) control subjects and 34 (87%) quitline subjects (p¼0.015, Fisher's exact test).
There was no difference in biochemically confirmed abstinence between groups when those who did not provide a urine sample were considered to be smoking or with multiple imputation analysis.
If those without a urine sample were excluded from analysis, those subjects in the quitline group were more likely to be abstinent.

a plan to quit once leaving the hospital; 3. that it was "very likely" they would be able to do so; and 4. that if they would decide to quit, they were more sure of success.
Responses to the two items assessing perceptions of health risks posed by smoking were associated with 30 - day, but not 6 - month, abstinence.

entities.text: assessing perceptions of health risks posed by smoking

text: Patients who completed at least one counseling session with the quitline were also more likely to be abstinent at 30 days and 6 months compared with those not completing counseling, as were those who completed two or more counseling sessions compared with those who completed one.
Patients who used NRT while in the hospital were not more likely to be abstinent at 6 months, nor were those participants who reported any NRT use since hospital discharge.
Factors associated with completion of at least one coaching call included planning to quit after discharge and feeling that smoking contributed to needing hospitalization.

The major finding of this study was that although a relatively high proportion of smokers self-reported abstinence from smoking at 6 months after hospital discharge, the quitline facilitation intervention did not improve abstinence rates compared with a standard brief stop-smoking intervention.

The trajectory of self-reported smoking resumption after hospital discharge was similar to prior reports, 3,17 with most resuming smoking within the first week, but relatively high abstinence rates (compared with spontaneous quit attempts in the general population) maintained for 6 months, consistent with the "teachable moment" effect of hospitalization.

The pattern of results regarding both trajectory and treatment effects as assessed by self-reported abstinence were similar regardless of the method used to account for subjects who were not contacted.
Consistent with the experience of others working with hospitalized patients, obtaining specimens for biochemical confirmation of smoking status was challenging.
3,17 Self-reported abstinence was more likely to be confirmed in the quitline group.
The reason for this finding is unclear, but it likely explains the higher confirmed 6 - month abstinence rates in the quitline group when missing data are excluded.
Given that confirmation was available in only approximately half of the patients, the significance of this finding in terms of actual differences in smoking behavior between groups is not clear.
There are several potential reasons why abstinence rates did not differ between groups.
A minority of patients in the quitline group actually received any quitline counseling and only 57 (19%) received the multiple counseling sessions that prior work suggests is necessary for efficacy.
Several factors could be responsible for this low utilization.
There were logistic challenges to connecting patients to counselors (e.g., short lengths of stay and interruptions for treatments and diagnostic testing).
The authors noted that patients were most likely to connect with counselors at the time of the intake call.
Thus, the authors worked with the quitline provider to maximize the immediate availability of counselors, and study personnel facilitated the calls.
However, with multiple other demands on patient time, even just completing the intake call was not always feasible.
In addition, because willingness to contact the quitline was not an inclusion criterion, some patients declined.
Interestingly, there was not a consistent relationship between self-efficacy and the receipt of coaching, perhaps because some expressing high self-efficacy did not feel a need for assistance.

The authors view the rate of counseling (43% receiving at least one coaching session in the quitline intervention group) as the maximum that could be achieved in a general hospitalized population in actual practice; this rate could be higher if only patients who were highly motivated to quit were approached.

However, within the intervention group, even those who reported they would be "very likely" to quit after leaving the hospital were not significantly more likely to be abstinent at 6 months than those in the control group who felt similarly (40% and 33% in intervention and control groups, respectively).
Even accounting for quitline utilization rates, there was still little evidence of quitline efficacy among those who used it.
Abstinence rates were greater in those completing at least one counseling session, with those completing two or more sessions having the highest rate.
However, the absence of any difference in rates between treatment groups suggests that counseling maybe simply a marker for those who would have quit in any event.

This is an important finding that may have relevance to the interpretation of prior observational studies of quitline efficacy-subjects who are going to quit regardless of any intervention maybe more likely to utilize interventions.
The high level of satisfaction with quitline services suggests that at least from the patient standpoint, poor quitline service quality was not responsible for lack of effectiveness.
There was no attempt to specifically tailor the counseling to hospitalized patients, and it is possible that such tailoring could enhance efficacy.
It is also possible that elements of the brief control intervention were efficacious, and that if the quitline intervention had been compared to no intervention, effectiveness would be revealed.
For example, both groups received access to NRT while hospitalized and the offer of 2 weeks of free NRT at discharge.
However, similar proportions of both groups used NRT and its use, either before or after discharge, was not associated with abstinence.
These findings suggest that NRT did not contribute to sustained abstinence.
It is possible that the duration of free NRT that was provided (2 weeks, chosen as potentially feasible for hospitals to provide) was insufficient for efficacy.

Also, the control intervention incorporated elements of brief clinical-delivered interventions shown to be efficacious in other settings; however, prior work in hospitalized patients suggests that post-discharge follow-up is necessary, 3,6 which was not provided in the control patients.
The fact that treatment group assignment did not affect abstinence rates provided the opportunity to perform pooled analyses examining factors predicting abstinence.
Consistent with prior findings in both ambulatory and hospitalized populations, 26 - 28 measures of intent and self-efficacy were significant predictors, as were lower levels of nicotine dependence.
Of interest, heightened perception of future health risks caused by smoking was not associated with abstinence, consistent with prior work in surgical patients.

entities.text: heightened perception of future health risks caused by smoking was not associated

text: This study had several additional limitations.

To minimize referral bias and provide an estimate of potential effectiveness when applied across a general population, the study examined a geographically defined population and attempted to recruit subjects regardless of motivation to quit.

Although the "sniffer" allowed rapid identification of potential subjects, not every potentially eligible patient was approached because of logistic considerations, and those not approached were less likely to evidence interest in quitting.
Also, although the consent rate among those approached was relatively high fora general population of smokers, it is apparent that those more motivated to quit were more likely to enroll.
Thus, if the intervention were applied as a matter of clinical routine to all patients, it is still unlikely it would be effective.

Although the majority of patients stated intent to quit after discharge, this proportion was slightly higher in the quitline group; however, this presumably would bias towards finding an effect in this group.
Finally, the Olmsted county population does not reflect the diversity of the overall U.S. population, so these results may not apply to other populations.

When combined with an offer of free NRT at hospital discharge, a brief intervention that facilitates utilization of telephone quitlines by hospitalized smokers for both in-hospital interventions and extended follow-up does not affect post-discharge self-reported abstinence rates compared with a brief 5A's intervention.

Although several factors maybe responsible for this finding, it may reflect, at least in part, that relatively few patients in this population-based cohort accepted the extended postdischarge counseling that prior work suggests is necessary for efficacy.

Thus, it is unlikely that currently available quitline services alone are useful dissemination tools to effectively intervene in hospitalized patients, and the search should continue for other effective, practical methods.
